hints.label: def-simplicial-homology
hints.title: Simplicial Homology
hints.content:
474: :label: def-simplicial-homology
475: 
476: For a simplicial complex $K$, define:
477: 
478: **Chain groups**: $C_k(K)$ is the free abelian group generated by $k$-simplices:
479: 
480: $$
481: C_k(K) := \bigoplus_{\sigma \in K_k} \mathbb{Z} \cdot \sigma
482: 
483: $$
484: 
485: where $K_k$ is the set of all $k$-simplices.
486: 
487: **Boundary operator**: $\partial_k: C_k \to C_{k-1}$ is the linear map:
488: 
489: $$
490: \partial_k([v_0, v_1, \ldots, v_k]) := \sum_{i=0}^{k} (-1)^i [v_0, \ldots, \hat{v}_i, \ldots, v_k]
491: 
492: $$
493: 
494: where $\hat{v}_i$ means omit vertex $v_i$.
495: 
496: **Fundamental property**: $\partial_{k-1} \circ \partial_k = 0$ (boundary of boundary is zero)
497: 
498: **Homology groups**:
499: 
500: $$
501: H_k(K) := \frac{\ker(\partial_k)}{\text{im}(\partial_{k+1})} = \frac{Z_k}{B_k}
502: 
503: $$
504: 
505: where:
506: - $Z_k := \ker(\partial_k)$ is the group of **$k$-cycles** (closed chains)
507: - $B_k := \text{im}(\partial_{k+1})$ is the group of **$k$-boundaries** (exact chains)
508: 
509: **Betti number recovery**:
510: 
511: $$
512: \beta_k := \text{rank}(H_k(K; \mathbb{Z}))
513: 
514: $$
515: 
516: This is the rank of the free part of the homology group $H_k(K)$ over integers $\mathbb{Z}$. For homology with coefficients in a field $\mathbb{F}$ (e.g., $\mathbb{Q}$ or $\mathbb{Z}_p$):
517: 
518: $$
519: \beta_k = \dim(H_k(K; \mathbb{F})) = \dim(Z_k) - \dim(B_k)
520: 
521: $$

hints.label: ex-homology-triangle
hints.title: Homology Computation for Triangle
hints.content:
527: :label: ex-homology-triangle
528: 
529: Consider a triangle $K$ with vertices $\{a, b, c\}$ and edges $\{[a,b], [b,c], [c,a]\}$ but **no 2-simplex** (hollow triangle).
530: 
531: **$H_0$ (0-dimensional homology)**:
532: - $C_0 = \langle a, b, c \rangle \cong \mathbb{Z}^3$
533: - $\partial_1([a,b]) = b - a$, $\partial_1([b,c]) = c - b$, $\partial_1([c,a]) = a - c$
534: - $Z_0 = C_0$ (all 0-chains are cycles)
535: - $B_0 = \text{span}\{b - a, c - b\} \cong \mathbb{Z}^2$
536: - $H_0 = \mathbb{Z}^3 / \mathbb{Z}^2 \cong \mathbb{Z}$ → $\beta_0 = 1$ (one connected component) ✓
537: 
538: **$H_1$ (1-dimensional homology)**:
539: - $C_1 = \langle [a,b], [b,c], [c,a] \rangle \cong \mathbb{Z}^3$
540: - $Z_1 = \ker(\partial_1) = \text{span}\{[a,b] + [b,c] + [c,a]\} \cong \mathbb{Z}$ (the loop)
541: - $B_1 = \{0\}$ (no 2-simplices, so no boundaries from higher dimension)
542: - $H_1 = Z_1 / B_1 \cong \mathbb{Z}$ → $\beta_1 = 1$ (one independent loop) ✓
543: 
544: If we **fill** the triangle (add 2-simplex $[a,b,c]$):

hints.label: alg-boundary-matrix
hints.title: Boundary Matrix Method for Homology
hints.content:
552: :label: alg-boundary-matrix
553: 
554: **Input**: Simplicial complex $K$ (e.g., Delaunay triangulation of walkers)
555: 
556: **Output**: Betti numbers $\beta_0, \beta_1, \ldots, \beta_d$
557: 
558: **Steps**:
559: 
560: 1. **Enumerate simplices**: List all $k$-simplices for $k = 0, 1, \ldots, d$
561: 
562: 2. **Construct boundary matrices**: For each $k$, build matrix $\partial_k$ where:
563:    - Rows index $(k-1)$-simplices
564:    - Columns index $k$-simplices
565:    - Entry $(i, j)$ is the coefficient of simplex $i$ in $\partial_k(\text{simplex } j)$
566: 
567: 3. **Compute ranks (over a field)**:
568:    - To compute Betti numbers over a field $\mathbb{F}$ (which is sufficient for counting holes), use Gaussian elimination:
569:    - $\text{rank}_\mathbb{F}(\partial_k)$ via row reduction over $\mathbb{F}$
570:    - $\dim(Z_k) = \dim(C_k) - \text{rank}_\mathbb{F}(\partial_k)$
571:    - $\dim(B_k) = \text{rank}_\mathbb{F}(\partial_{k+1})$
572: 
573: 4. **Betti numbers**:
574: 
575: $$
576: \beta_k = \dim(Z_k) - \dim(B_k) = \dim(C_k) - \text{rank}_\mathbb{F}(\partial_k) - \text{rank}_\mathbb{F}(\partial_{k+1})
577: 
578: $$
579: 
580: **For full integer homology** (including torsion): Use **Smith Normal Form** on the boundary matrices $\partial_k$ over $\mathbb{Z}$. This gives the torsion coefficients as well as the free rank.
581: 
582: **Complexity**: $O(n^3)$ where $n$ is the total number of cells (dominated by matrix reduction via Gaussian elimination over a field). Smith Normal Form over $\mathbb{Z}$ for full integer homology has comparable or worse complexity but provides torsion information. Fast matrix multiplication algorithms (ω < 3) do not apply to sparse boundary matrices in practical homology computations.

hints.label: rem-cohomology-vs-homology
hints.title: Cohomology vs Homology
hints.content:
588: :label: rem-cohomology-vs-homology
589: 
590: **Cohomology** groups $H^k(K)$ are the dual of homology:
591: 
592: $$
593: H^k(K) := \frac{\ker(\delta^k)}{\text{im}(\delta^{k-1})}
594: 
595: $$
596: 
597: where $\delta^k: C^k \to C^{k+1}$ is the **coboundary operator** on cochains $C^k := \text{Hom}(C_k, \mathbb{Z})$.
598: 
599: **Why cohomology matters**:
600: - Cohomology has a **ring structure** (cup product) → richer algebraic invariants
601: - More natural for differential forms and de Rham cohomology
602: - Connection to gauge theory: cohomology classes classify gauge bundles
603: 
604: **For Fragile framework**:
605: - Homology is typically sufficient for counting topological features
606: - Cohomology becomes relevant for gauge-theoretic formulations (see Part 6)
